message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A palpable perianal mass suggests thrombosed external hemorrhoids. Elliptical excision is the most appropriate immediate management as it can relieve symptoms faster and with lower recurrence rates compared to other options. Incision and drainage can be considered if there is a visible abscess. Rubber band ligation and sclerotherapy are not appropriate for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The palpable perianal mass suggests thrombosed external hemorrhoids. Elliptical excision is the most appropriate immediate management for this condition. Incision and drainage are usually performed for abscesses or infected lesions. Rubber band ligation and sclerotherapy are used for internal hemorrhoids.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a palpable perianal mass suggests a thrombosed external hemorrhoid, which can be treated with elliptical excision. Incision and drainage are not recommended, as this may increase the risk of infection. Rubber band ligation and sclerotherapy are used for internal hemorrhoids.

We refer to Mayo Clinic for help. The presence of a palpable perianal mass suggests an external hemorrhoid that has thrombosed. The most appropriate immediate management is elliptical excision to remove the clot and relieve the pain. Incision and drainage are not recommended as it could increase the risk of infection, and rubber band ligation and sclerotherapy are not appropriate for thrombosed external hemorrhoids.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The palpable mass and lack of skin tag or mucosal prolapse suggest an acute thrombosed external hemorrhoid. Elliptical excision is the most appropriate immediate management for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The perianal mass suggests a thrombosed external hemorrhoid. The most appropriate immediate management is elliptical excision to relieve the pain and prevent recurrence. Incision and drainage should not be done as it can lead to an open wound with increased risk of infection. Rubber band ligation and sclerotherapy are not appropriate for thrombosed external hemorrhoids.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The perianal mass is most likely a thrombosed external hemorrhoid, which can be treated with elliptical excision to relieve the pain and remove the clot. Incision and drainage is not recommended because it may cause further damage and infection. Rubber band ligation and sclerotherapy are used for internal hemorrhoids.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a palpable perianal mass suggests a thrombosed external hemorrhoid. The most appropriate immediate management is elliptical excision to remove the thrombosed part of the hemorrhoid. Incision and drainage is not appropriate as it may cause further bleeding and complications. Rubber band ligation and sclerotherapy are used for non-thrombosed hemorrhoids.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The palpable perianal mass suggests an anal fissure or perianal abscess, and elliptical excision is the most appropriate immediate management for an anal fissure or hemorrhoid. Incision and drainage are appropriate for a perianal abscess, and rubber band ligation or sclerotherapy are used for hemorrhoids.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a palpable perianal mass suggests an external hemorrhoid. Elliptical excision is the most appropriate immediate management for a thrombosed external hemorrhoid. Incision and drainage or sclerotherapy may be used for an abscess or internal hemorrhoids, respectively, and rubber band ligation is used for non-thrombosed internal hemorrhoids.
